Face Coverings at GSD:
On July 1, 2020, the Secretary of the Pennsylvania Department of Health announced an order requiring universal face coverings.

Schools should provide face covering breaks throughout the day. Maintain a distance of 6 feet during these face covering breaks. Schools may allow students to remove their face covering when students are:

1. Eating or drinking when spaced at least 6 feet apart;
2. Seated at desks or assigned work spaces at least 6 feet apart; or
3. Engaged in an activity at least 6 feet apart (e.g. face covering breaks, recess, etc.)
4. When wearing a face covering creates an unsafe condition in which to operate equipment or execute a task.

‚ÄúFace covering‚Äù means a covering of the nose and mouth that is secured to the head with ties, straps, or loops over the ears or is wrapped around the lower face. A ‚Äúface covering‚Äù can be made of a variety of synthetic or natural fabrics, including cotton, silk or linen, and, for purposes of the order, can include a plastic face shield that covers the nose and mouth.
#GirardBuzz

post_text: In Miss Davenport‚Äôs 4th grade classes, students constructed a simple model of a watershed, which is an area of land that drains runoff into a body of water. In a two-part investigation, students crumpled paper and carefully outlined high points of land and marked low points of land where they thought water would collect. Using a spray bottle, students created a ‚Äúrainstorm‚Äù to observe where rainfall accumulated, while observing the pathways where water traveled. On the second day, students created a similar model, this time adding houses, landfills, farms, and factories to investigate how decisions made by humans affect our land. #GirardBuzz

The NWPA Tobacco Control Program from the Erie County Department of Health recently provided an educational program on the dangers of vaping to all students at RAMS. The highlight of the program was the live comparison of fetal pig lungs, one set which had been exposed to the chemicals contained in e-cigarettes, and one set which had not. The visual comparison between the size, color, and functioning of the two sets of lungs was profound. Presenters Michelle Armendariz Hall and Niki Knopsnyder were very clear in their message to students that vaping harms overall health, especially when it comes to developing adolescents.

RAMS thanks Davina Knight of Coalition Pathways and the RAMS Epic Outreach program for bringing this educational opportunity to students. #GirardBuzz

Monday Morning- Meet the Teacher!

Introducing Mr. John Bochicchio, GHS Business and Technical Education teacher. Mr. Bochicchio has been with GSD for 27 years!

Mr. Bochicchio served 5 years in the Army Reserves as a Military Police Officer, and 1 year Active Duty during Desert Storm/Shield. He owns a Landscaping and Snowplowing business, as well as owned a Home Maintenance and Repair Business.

He works as a Case Manager for the law firm Law4Veterans, where he helps disabled veterans with all communications with Veterans Administration.

In his spare time, he likes to spend time with his wife and kids, workout at the gym, go to the shooting range and remodel his home.

When asked why he loves working for GSD: I love working for Girard because of the level of respect that I have always received from administration. They have always treated me as a valuable member of the district and not just another employee. GSD is the heartbeat of this community, and I love being a part of what we do here!

Thank you Mr. Bochicchio for all you do! #GirardBuzz

Monday Morning - Meet the Teacher!

Introducing Ms. Antonella Spinelli, Business/Career Teacher at Girard High School. Ms. Spinelli has been with the GSD for 27 years, three of which she taught at RAMS.

She has two children- AJ and Gabriella. Ms. Spinelli enjoys working out, watching the Steelers, reading and cooking.

A fun fact about Ms. Spinelli- she is first generation Italian/American. Her parents were born and raised in Italy, got married and moved to Glassport, PA. The majority of her family still live in Italy. Ms. Spinelli spoke fluent Italian in her younger years.

When asked why she enjoys working for the GSD: My job at the GSD has evolved to a position where I am able to help kids make important decisions on their futures! It is fulfilling when they are excited about their future. I have been able to make many connections with the community in my job and bring many career experiences to the schools. The best part of the job is when graduates express how much I have helped prepare them for success!

Thank you Ms. Spinelli for all you do! #GirardBuzz
